case_vignette:
A 58-year old man comes to his physician because of a 1-month history of increased thirst and nocturia. He is drinking a lot of water to compensate for any dehydration. His brother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 151 mEq/L and glucose of 121 mg/dL. A water deprivation test shows:
Serum osmolality
(mOsmol/kg H2O) Urine osmolality
(mOsmol/kg H2O)
Initial presentation 295 285
After 3 hours without fluids 305 310
After administration of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) analog 280 355
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing increased thirst and needing to go to the bathroom a lot during the night.
Great, thank you for sharing that information. Have you noticed any changes in your urine output or color?
No, I didn't mention anything about changes in my urine output or color.
My apologies, I misunderstood. Can you tell me more about the frequency of your nocturnal urination? How often are you getting up to use the bathroom during the night?
I've just mentioned needing to go to the bathroom a lot during the night, but I didn't specify exactly how often.
Okay, no problem. Have you experienced any recent changes in your fluid intake or activity level that could be contributing to your increased thirst and nighttime urination?
I've been drinking a lot of water to make up for feeling dehydrated.
Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some questions about your medical history. Have you ever been diagnosed with diabetes or hypertension?
My brother has type 2 diabetes, but I didn't mention having it myself or hypertension.
My apologies for the oversight. Here's my next question: Have you noticed any other symptoms, such as increased thirst, fatigue, or blurred vision?
Yes, I've noticed increased thirst.

Great, that helps to narrow it down. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some questions about your medication history. Have you recently started or stopped taking any medications, or changed the dosage of any medications?
I didn't mention anything about taking or changing medications.
My apologies for the oversight. Here's my next question: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight recently?
No, I haven't mentioned any changes in my appetite or weight.

Okay, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some questions about your family medical history. Have any of your close relatives, such as parents or siblings, been diagnosed with diabetes or any other endocrine disorders?
My brother has type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Great, that helps to narrow it down. Based on your symptoms and your brother's diagnosis, I would like to ask you some questions about your body mass index (BMI). Have you noticed any recent changes in your weight or body shape?
I didn't mention any changes in my weight or body shape.

Okay, no problem. Based on what you've told me so far, I would like to perform a physical examination to check for any abnormalities in your body. Can you please undress to your waist and turn around so I can inspect your abdomen?
During my physical examination, it was noted that I have dry mucous membranes.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and the physical examination findings, I would like to perform some additional tests to help confirm the diagnosis. Can you please provide a urine sample for analysis?
During the tests, my initial urine was found to be concentrated.

Great, that helps to confirm the diagnosis. Based on your symptoms and test results, I believe you may have developed diabetes insipidus. This is a rare condition that affects the body's ability to regulate fluid levels, leading to excessive thirst and urination.

To confirm the diagnosis, I would like to perform a water deprivation test. This involves abstaining from water intake for a certain period of time and measuring your urine output during that time. This will help us determine the effectiveness of your kidneys in concentrating urine and confirm the diagnosis of diabetes insipidus.

Are you willing to undergo this test? If so, we can schedule it for [insert time].
